awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance the understanding of the development of strategic decision-making in children and adolescents by assessing the contribution of logical and strategic thinking to decision-making abilities. Strategic thinking is critical to make everyday decisions and such decisions often involve other players who have different motivations and perspectives. These differences must be understood at the time of decision to make logical and informed decisions. Research has shown that adults have innate abilities to coordinate on efficient market outcomes even with very limited knowledge. At the same time, they have limited abilities to anticipate what others may do and to strategize in a large variety of multi-person situations, such as bargaining. This suggests that some abilities develop while others do not. An important objective of the project is to study how children develop (or do not develop) these abilities and to better understand the reasons for irrational choices in adults. Also, the project will allow to better assess the limitations in the acquisition and transfer of cognitive skills to decision-making. This will help determine whether cognitive skills and rational behavior can be enhanced. Last, the study may help explore new curriculum development strategies and inform interventions around children and teenagers. Indeed, one essential role of education is to promote critical thinking. Education is thus expected to impact positively the way we make decisions. Our study will contribute to the design of an educational environment capable of promoting success beyond school-related attainment. 

The study will feature four sets of lab-in-the field experiments. School-age students from Pre-K to 12th grade will be recruited from public and private schools in the Los Angeles area. For comparison, adult controls will also be recruited. Each experiment will evaluate the performance of each participant on tasks designed to assess cognitive traits and on game theoretic paradigms that require those underlying cognitive traits. Four game theoretic paradigms in which adults comply differentially with equilibrium predictions will be studied. The first experiment will investigate how humans develop their innate ability to coordinate on efficient solutions in repeated relationships. The second experiment will explore strategic situations in which adults are largely heterogeneous in their ability to anticipate what others will do and to formulate a best response. The third experiment will explore the underlying causes that make mixed strategy behavior non-intuitive and difficult to implement. The last experiment will investigate the reasons why the ability to strategize does not develop naturally in the presence of informational asymmetries. The study will allow to identify behavioral biases that develop gradually. Tracking biases to their developmental causes is important to inform research in Economics and to develop theoretical models with better predictive power. At the same time, the study will offer clues that may be used to remedy such biases. The study will help assess whether limitations of strategic thinking abilities stem from an imperfect acquisition of cognitive skills, which may be remedied by exposing children to specific problems and teaching them how to think about them.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research carried out through this grant has explored the developmental trajectory of strategic decision-making in children and adolescents across various game theory scenarios. Behavior in these situations builds upon two primary cognitive skills: logical reasoning, which encompasses a wide range of individual cognitive abilities, and theory of mind (ToM), which involves the capacity to understand and assess the beliefs and motivations of others. Our findings reveal that even as young as 4 years old, children demonstrate logical reasoning abilities, yet their performance is hindered by complexity. Actively considering their partner's decisions before making their own choices helped overcome these difficulties, but logical reasoning and ToM are more effectively applied in simpler games necessitating little consideration of others? mental states. We tracked these abilities by designing games that required varying combinations of logical thinking and ToM skills.

We examined games heavily reliant on logical abilities and demanding iterative algorithms. We found that feedback played a pivotal role in learning during childhood, with notable development during elementary school that tended to stabilize afterwards in games of complete information. In contrast, contingent reasoning abilities, crucial for games involving asymmetric information, exhibited continued development throughout adolescence but never fully matured. Furthermore, in games that required unpredictability, such as in a hide and seek context, we observed no developmental progression of randomization skills. This complex form of logic remained absent across all ages, as players frequently favored actions with potentially high payoffs, making them predictable and exploitable by their partners. 

We also explored games heavily reliant on the ability to read others? mind. Examples include games where logical arguments result in low payoffs. In such games, adults recognize their own and others? benefit of departing from logical thinking and collectively coordinate on departures.  Our study revealed that the development of theory of mind played a pivotal role in deviating from logical arguments when it was advantageous. In a similar vein, when investigating games requiring coordination, we noticed a consistent increase in the ability to coordinate on efficient outcomes across children and adults. This highlighted a gradual acquisition of intention-sharing and belief-sharing skills, constrained by game complexity. Additionally, our research revealed that children could skip developmental stages when briefly exposed to coordination problems. Also, our study delved into early trading tendencies, finding that market equilibrium outcomes were common in barter economies and commodity markets. Around 50% of children aged 5 to 7 consistently engaged in efficient pairwise trades, demonstrating their ability to combine logic and the ability to engage with others for favorable market outcomes.

Across all our studies, we noted significant heterogeneity within age groups. A few young children often outperform adults across paradigms. High cognitive ability correlated particularly with long iterations and simple contingent reasoning, though complex contingent reasoning tasks remained challenging. Environmental factors also played a role, as participants with STEM interests, high socioeconomic status, or attending private schools tend to exhibit better performance. These findings have important implications for interventions that we plan to leverage in further studies and dissemination campaigns, in partnership with the schools that facilitate our research.

Collectively, our results emphasize the early development of logic and ToM, each applied differentially based on task demands. Humans possess an inherent ability to understand others' minds, but logical abilities require more effort and are not universally mastered in interactive settings. Biological and environmental constraints also place bounds on performance.

The award also resulted in educational initiatives, training programs, research dissemination, interdisciplinary partnerships, and software innovation, all with the shared aim of promoting interest for decision-making and its age-related changes.

We have worked closely with participating schools, offering the "Little Experimentalists" program to children, involving parents through information sharing, and training educators. This initiative introduces children to decision-making, game theory, logic, and math, while high school students engage in yearly case studies and internships.

Our comprehensive "Training Program" spans both remote and in-person learning, welcoming high-schoolers (10 to 15 per year) and college students (5 to 10 per year) globally. Students are involved in research projects resulting in collaborative scientific reports disseminated through social media, newsletters, and our website. Additionally, students craft scientific essays to publish in our ?High School Journal?, honing their analytical and writing skills while exploring interdisciplinary intersections of economics, psychology, and biology.

At USC, we have introduced a "Psychology and Economics" major and a "Behavioral Economics" track at the graduate level, which immerse students in our research endeavors.

Conferences and workshops facilitate the exchange of developmental decision-making insights, complemented by an ongoing virtual special issue. We've also authored a methodological paper outlining the intricacies of studying children's behavior, offering guidelines for conducting such studies. Last, our open-source software applications and study materials tailored to each experiment and shared through GitHub, promote replication, and serve as pedagogical aids in classrooms.
